18.verse: He ·helps [grants justice to] orphans and widows, and he loves ·foreigners [resident aliens] and gives them food and clothes.

19.verse: You also must love ·foreigners [resident aliens], because you were ·foreigners [resident aliens] in Egypt.

20.verse: ·Respect [Fear] the LORD your God and serve him. ·Be loyal [Cling] to him and ·make your promises in [swear by] his name.

21.verse: He is the one you should praise; he is your God, who has done great and ·wonderful [awesome] things for you, which you have seen with your own eyes.

22.verse: There were only seventy of your ·ancestors [fathers] when they went down to Egypt [Gen. 46:26; Ex. 1:5], and now the LORD your God has made you as many as the stars in the sky [Gen. 15:5; 22:19].

1.verse: Great Things Israel Saw - Love the LORD your God and always obey his orders, ·rules [statutes; ordinances; requirements], laws, and commands.

2.verse: ·Remember [You know] today it was not your children who saw and ·felt [experienced; knew] the ·correction [discipline] of the LORD your God. They did not see his ·majesty [greatness], his ·power [strong hand], his ·strength [outstretched arm],

3.verse: or his signs and the things he did in Egypt to Pharaoh, the king, and his whole country.

4.verse: They did not see what he did to the Egyptian army, its horses and chariots, when he drowned them in the ·Red [or Reed] Sea [Ex. 10:19] as they were chasing you. The LORD ·ruined [destroyed] them forever.

5.verse: They did not see what he did for you in the ·desert [wilderness] until you arrived here.

6.verse: They did not see what he did to Dathan and Abiram, the sons of Eliab the Reubenite, when the ground opened ·up [its mouth] and swallowed them, their ·families [houses], their tents, and everyone who stood ·with them in Israel [on their feet in all Israel; Num. 16].

7.verse: It was ·you who [your eyes that] saw all these great things the LORD has done.

8.verse: So ·obey [keep] all the commands I am ·giving [commanding] you today so that you will be strong and can go in and ·take [possess] the land you are ·going to take as your own [crossing over to possess].

9.verse: Then you will live a long time in the land that the LORD ·promised [swore] to give to your ·ancestors [fathers] and their ·descendants [seed], a ·fertile land [land flowing with milk and honey; Ex. 3:8].

10.verse: The land you are going to take is not like Egypt, where you were. There you had to plant your seed and water it, like a vegetable garden, by using your feet.

11.verse: But the land that you will soon cross ·the Jordan River [there] to ·take [possess] is a land of hills and valleys, ·a land that drinks [watered by] rain from heaven.

12.verse: It is a land the LORD your God ·cares for [looks after]. His eyes are on it continually, and he watches it from the beginning of the year to the end.

13.verse: If you carefully ·obey [listen to] the commands I am ·giving [commanding] you today and love the LORD your God and serve him with ·your whole being [all your heart/mind and all your soul],

14.verse: then he will send rain on your land at the right time, in the ·fall [early rain] and ·spring [late rain], and you will be able to gather your grain, new wine, and oil.

15.verse: He will put grass in the fields for your cattle, and you will have plenty to eat.

16.verse: Be careful, or you will be ·fooled [tricked; deceived; seduced] and will turn away to serve and worship other gods.

17.verse: If you do, the LORD will become angry with you and will ·shut [close up] the heavens so it will not rain [1 Kin. 17:1]. Then the land will not ·grow [produce] crops, and you will soon ·die [perish] in the good land the LORD is giving you.

18.verse: ·Remember my words with your whole being [Put these words of mine on your hearts/minds and on your soul]. ·Write them down and tie [Bind] them to your hands as a sign; tie them ·on your foreheads [between your eyes] ·to remind you [as an emblem/headband/frontlet; 6:8].

19.verse: Teach them well to your children, talking about them when you sit at home and walk along the road, when you lie down and when you get up.

20.verse: Write them on ·your doors [the lintels/doorposts of your house] and gates

21.verse: so that both you and your children will live a long time in the land the LORD promised your ·ancestors [fathers], as long as the ·skies [heavens] are above the earth.

22.verse: If you are careful to obey every command I am ·giving you to follow [commanding you to do], and love the LORD your God, and ·do what he has told you to do [walk on all his ways/paths], and ·are loyal [cling] to him,

23.verse: then the LORD will ·force [dispossess] all those nations out of the land ahead of you, and you will ·take [possess] the land from nations that are bigger and stronger than you.

24.verse: Everywhere ·you step [the heel of your foot treads] will be yours. Your land will go from the ·desert [wilderness] to Lebanon and from the Euphrates River to the ·Mediterranean [Great] Sea.

25.verse: No one will be able to ·stop [stand against] you. The LORD your God will ·do what he promised and will make the people afraid everywhere you go [put the dread and fear of you on all the land on which you tread as he promised].

26.verse: See, today I am ·letting you choose [setting before you] a blessing or a curse.

27.verse: You will be blessed if you obey the commands of the LORD your God that I am ·giving [commanding] you today.

28.verse: But you will be cursed if you ·disobey [do not listen to] the commands of the LORD your God. So do not ·disobey the commands [turn aside from the way] I am ·giving [commanding] you today, and do not ·worship [go after] other gods you do not know.

29.verse: When the LORD your God brings you into the land you will ·take as your own [possess], you are to announce the blessings from Mount Gerizim and the curses from Mount Ebal [27–28; Josh. 8:30–35].

30.verse: (·These mountains are [Are they not…?] ·on the other side of [beyond] the Jordan River, to the west, toward the sunset. They are near the great trees of Moreh [Gen. 12:6] in the land of the Canaanites who live in the ·Jordan Valley [Arabah] opposite Gilgal.)

31.verse: You will soon cross the Jordan River to enter and ·take [possess] the land the LORD your God is giving you. When you ·take it over [possess it] and live there,

32.verse: be careful to obey all the commands and ·laws [statutes; ordinances; requirements] I am giving you today.

1.verse: The Place for Worship - These are the ·commands [statutes; ordinances; requirements] and laws you must carefully obey in the land the LORD, the God of your ·ancestors [fathers], is giving you to possess. Obey them as long as you live in the land.

2.verse: When you ·inherit [possess] the lands of these nations, you must completely destroy all the places where they serve their gods, on high mountains and hills and under every green tree.

3.verse: Tear down their altars, smash their holy stone pillars, and burn their ·Asherah idols [Asherim; 7:5; Judg. 3:7] in the fire. Cut down their idols and destroy their names from those places.

4.verse: Don’t ·worship [act for] the LORD your God that way,

5.verse: but look for the place the LORD your God will choose—·a place among your tribes where he is to be worshiped [as his dwelling where he will place his name]. Go there,

6.verse: and bring to that place your burnt offerings [Lev. 1:1–17] and sacrifices; bring ·a tenth of what you gain [your tithes] and your special gifts; bring what you have ·promised [vowed] and the special gifts you want to give the LORD, and bring the first animals born to your herds and flocks.

7.verse: There you and your families will eat in the presence of the LORD, and you will enjoy all ·the good things for which you have worked [your undertakings; all that is sent out from your hand], because the LORD your God has blessed you.

8.verse: Do not ·worship [act] the way we have been ·doing [acting] today, each person doing what ·he thinks is right [is right/virtuous in his own eyes].

9.verse: You have not yet come to a resting place, to the ·land [inheritance] the LORD your God will give you as your own.

10.verse: But soon you will cross the Jordan River to live in the land the LORD your God is ·giving you as your own [causing you to inherit], where he will give you rest from all your enemies and you will live in safety [2 Sam. 7:1; David would achieve rest from enemies; Solomon would build the temple in an era of peace].

11.verse: Then the LORD your God will choose a place where he ·is to be worshiped [will cause his name to dwell; Zion, where the Temple would be built]. To that place you must bring everything I ·tell [command] you: your burnt offerings [Lev. 1:1–17] and sacrifices, your ·offerings of a tenth of what you gain [tithes], your special gifts, and all your best things you ·promised [vowed] to the LORD.

12.verse: There rejoice before the LORD your God. Everyone should rejoice: you, your sons and daughters, your male and female servants, and the Levites ·from your towns [in your gates] who have no ·land [allotment] of their own.

13.verse: Be careful that you don’t sacrifice your burnt offerings [Lev. 1:1–17] just anywhere you ·please [see].

14.verse: Offer them only in the place the LORD will choose [Zion; v. 11]. He will choose a place in one of your tribes, and there you must do everything I am commanding you.

15.verse: But you may ·kill [slaughter] your animals in any of your ·towns [gates] and eat ·as much of the meat as you want [as much of the meat as your soul desires; or when your soul desires], as if it were a deer or a gazelle; this is the blessing the LORD your God is giving you. Anyone, clean or unclean [in a ritual sense], may eat this meat,

16.verse: but do not eat the blood [Gen. 9:4; Lev. 3:17; Acts 15:20, 29]. Pour it out on the ground like water.

17.verse: Do not eat in your own ·towns [gates] what belongs to the LORD: ·one-tenth [a tithe] of your grain, new wine, or oil; the first animals born to your herds or flocks; whatever you have ·promised to give [vowed]; the special gifts you want to give to the LORD, or any other gifts.

18.verse: Eat these things when you are together with the LORD your God, in the place the LORD your God chooses to be worshiped. Everyone must do this: you, your sons and daughters, your male and female servants, and the Levites from your ·towns [gates]. Rejoice in the LORD your God’s presence about ·the things you have worked for [your undertakings; all that is sent out from your hand].

19.verse: Be careful not to ·forget [abandon; forsake] the Levites as long ·as you live [all your days] in the land.

20.verse: When the LORD your God enlarges your ·country [borders] as he has promised, and ·you want [your soul desires] some meat so you say, “I want some meat,” you may eat ·as much meat as you want [what your soul desires; or when your soul desires].

21.verse: If the LORD your God chooses a place where he ·is to be worshiped [puts his name] that is too far away from you, you may ·kill [slaughter] animals from your herds and flocks, which the LORD has given to you. I have commanded that you may do this. You may eat ·as much of them as you want [as much as your soul desires; or when your soul desires] in your own ·towns [gates],

22.verse: as you would eat gazelle or deer meat. Both clean and unclean people [in a ritual sense] may eat this meat,

23.verse: but be sure you don’t eat the blood, because the life is in the blood [Gen. 9:4; Lev. 3:17; Acts 15:20, 29]. Don’t eat the life with the meat.

24.verse: Don’t eat the blood, but pour it out on the ground like water.

25.verse: If you don’t eat it, things will go well for you and your children, because you will be doing what ·the LORD says is right [is right/virtuous in the eyes of the LORD].

26.verse: Take your holy ·things [gifts; donations] and ·the things you have promised to give [your vows that you have lifted up], and go to the place the LORD will choose.

27.verse: Present your burnt offerings [Lev. 1:1–17] on the altar of the LORD your God, both the meat and the blood. The blood of your sacrifices should be poured beside the altar of the LORD your God, but you may eat the meat.

28.verse: Be careful to ·obey [listen to] all the rules I am ·giving [commanding] you so that things will always go well for you and your children, and you will be doing what the LORD your God says is good and ·right [virtuous in his eyes].

29.verse: You will enter the land and ·take it away from [dispossess] the nations that the LORD your God will ·destroy [cut them off] ahead of you. When you ·force them out [dispossess] and live in their land,

30.verse: they will be destroyed for you, but be careful not to be ·trapped [snared] by asking about their gods. Don’t say, “How do these nations ·worship [serve]? I will do the same.”

31.verse: Don’t ·worship [act toward] the LORD your God that way, because the LORD hates the ·evil [detestable; abhorrent; abominable] ways they ·worship [act toward] their gods. They even burn their sons and daughters as sacrifices to their gods!

32.verse: Be sure to do everything I have commanded you. Do not add anything to it, and do not take anything away from it.

1.verse: False Prophets - Prophets or ·those who tell the future with dreams [dreamers of dreams] might come to you and ·say they will show [give] you a sign or a ·miracle [wonder].

2.verse: The sign or ·miracle [wonder] might even happen, and then they might say, “Let’s serve other gods” (gods you have not known) “and let’s ·worship [go after] them.”

3.verse: But you must not listen to those prophets or dreamers. The LORD your God is testing you, to ·find out [know] if you love him with ·your whole being [all your heart/mind and all your soul].

4.verse: Serve only the LORD your God. ·Respect [Fear] him, keep his commands, and ·obey him [listen to his voice]. Serve him and ·be loyal [cling] to him.

5.verse: The prophets or dreamers must be killed, because they said you should turn against the LORD your God, who brought you out of Egypt and ·saved [ransomed; redeemed] you from the ·land where you were slaves [house of bondage]. They tried to turn you from ·doing what [the way] the LORD your God commanded you to ·do [go]. You must ·get rid of [banish; purge] the evil among you.

6.verse: Someone might try to ·lead you to serve other gods [secretly entice you]—it might be your brother, your son or daughter, the wife you ·love [embrace], or a ·close [intimate] friend. The person might say, “Let’s go and worship other gods.” (These are gods that neither you nor your ·ancestors [fathers] have known,

7.verse: gods of the people who live around you, either nearby or far away, from one end of the ·land [or earth] to the other.)

8.verse: Do not ·give in to [agree with; consent to] such people. Do not listen or ·feel sorry for [let your eyes look compassionately on] them, and do not ·let them go free [pity them] or ·protect [shield] them.

9.verse: You must ·put them to death [kill them]. ·You must be the first one to start [Your own hand will be the first on them] to kill them, and then ·everyone else must join in [the hand of all the people].

10.verse: You must ·throw stones at them until they die [stone them to death], because they tried to turn you away from the LORD your God, who brought you out of the land of Egypt, ·where you were slaves [the house of bondage].

11.verse: Then everyone in Israel will hear about this and be afraid, and no one among you will ever do such an evil thing again.

12.verse: Cities to Destroy - The LORD your God is giving you cities in which to live, and you might hear something about one of them. Someone might say

13.verse: that ·evil people [worthless people; scoundrels] have moved in among you. And they might lead the people of that city away from God, saying, “Let’s go and ·worship [serve] other gods.” (These are gods you have not known.)

14.verse: Then you must ask about it, ·looking into [investigating] the matter and checking carefully whether it is true. If it is proved that a ·hateful [detestable; abhorrent; abominable] thing has happened among you,

15.verse: you must ·kill [strike] with a sword everyone who lives in that city. ·Destroy the city completely and kill everyone in it [Devote that city to the LORD; 20:15–18; Josh. 6:17], as well as the animals, with a sword.

16.verse: Gather up ·everything those people owned [all its plunder], and put it in the middle of the city square. Then completely burn the city and ·everything they owned [all its plunder] as a burnt offering [Lev. 1:1–17] to the LORD your God. That city should never be rebuilt; let it be ·ruined [a ruin heap] forever.

17.verse: Don’t ·keep for yourselves [grasp in your hand] any of the ·things found in that city [devoted things; 20:15–18; Josh. 6:17], so the LORD will not be angry anymore. He will give you ·mercy and feel sorry for you, and he […mercy/compassion, and his mercy/compassion] will make your nation grow larger, as he ·promised [swore] to your ·ancestors [fathers].

18.verse: You will have ·obeyed [listened to the voice of] the LORD your God by keeping all his commands that I am ·giving [commanding] to you today, and you will be doing what ·the LORD says is right [is right/virtuous in the eyes of the LORD].

1.verse: God’s Special People - You are the ·children [sons] of the LORD your God. When someone dies, do not ·cut [lacerate; gash] yourselves or ·shave your heads [set baldness between your eyes; to show sadness; mourning customs of the pagan Canaanites].

2.verse: You are holy people, who belong to the LORD your God. He has chosen you from all the people on earth ·to be his very own [as his special treasure; Ex. 19:5–6].

3.verse: Do not eat anything ·the LORD hates [detestable; abominable; cf. Lev. 11].

4.verse: These are the animals you may eat: oxen, sheep, goats,

5.verse: deer, gazelle, roe deer, wild goats, ibex, antelope, and mountain sheep.

6.verse: You may eat any animal that has a split hoof and chews the cud [considered a normal land animal],

7.verse: but you may not eat camels, rabbits, or rock badgers. These animals chew the cud, but they do not have split hoofs, so they are unclean [in a ritual sense] for you.

8.verse: Pigs are also unclean for you; they have split hoofs, but they do not chew the cud. Do not eat their meat or touch their dead bodies.

9.verse: There are many things that live in the water. You may eat anything that has fins and scales [considered a normal aquatic creature],

10.verse: but do not eat anything that does not have fins and scales. It is unclean [in a ritual sense] for you.

11.verse: You may eat any clean [in a ritual sense] bird.

12.verse: But do not eat these birds: eagles, vultures, black vultures,

13.verse: red kites, falcons, any kind of kite,

14.verse: any kind of raven,

15.verse: horned owls, screech owls, sea gulls, any kind of hawk,

16.verse: little owls, great owls, white owls,

17.verse: desert owls, ospreys, cormorants,

18.verse: storks, any kind of heron, the hoopoes, or bats [the exact identification of many of these birds is disputed, but they all eat prey or dead matter and/or live in desolate places].

19.verse: All insects with wings are unclean [in a ritual sense] for you; do not eat them.

20.verse: Other things with wings are clean, and you may eat them.

21.verse: Do not eat anything you find that is already dead. You may give it to a ·foreigner living in your town [resident alien living within your gates], and he may eat it, or you may sell it to a foreigner. But you are holy people, who belong to the LORD your God. Do not cook a baby goat in its mother’s milk [probably a pagan ritual; Ex. 23:19].

22.verse: Giving a Tithe - Be sure to ·save [set aside/apart] ·one-tenth [a tithe] of all ·your crops [the produce/yield of your seed of the field] each year.

23.verse: Eat it in the presence of the LORD your God in the place where he chooses to ·be worshiped [cause his name to dwell; Zion; 12:4–7]. Eat the ·tenth [tithe] of your grain, new wine, and oil, and eat the animals born first to your herds and flocks. Do this so that you will learn to ·respect [fear] the LORD your God ·always [every day].

24.verse: But if the place the LORD will choose to ·be worshiped [set his name there] is too far away and he has blessed you so much you cannot carry a ·tenth [tithe],

25.verse: exchange your ·one-tenth [tithe] for silver. Then ·take [grasp in your hand] the silver with you to the place the LORD your God shall choose.

26.verse: ·Use [Spend; Give] the silver to buy anything you wish—cattle, sheep, wine, ·beer [strong drink; an alcoholic beverage made from grain], or anything you wish. Then you and your ·family [house] will eat and celebrate there before the LORD your God.

27.verse: Do not ·forget [abandon; forsake] the Levites in your ·town [gates], because they have no land of their own among you.

28.verse: At the end of every third year, everyone should bring ·one-tenth [a tithe] of that year’s crop and store it in your ·towns [gates].

29.verse: This is for the Levites so they may eat and be full. (They have no ·land of their own [allotment or inheritance] among you.) It is also for ·strangers [foreigners; resident aliens], orphans, and widows who live in your ·towns [gates] so that all of them may eat and be full. Then the LORD your God will bless you and all the work ·you do [of your hands that you do].

1.verse: The Special Seventh Year - At the end of every seven years, you must ·tell those who owe you anything that they do not have to pay you back [grant remission of debts; Ex. 23:10–11].

2.verse: This is ·how you must do it [the manner of remission]: Everyone who has ·loaned money [a claim] must ·cancel [remit] the loan and not make a neighbor or ·relative [or countryman; brother] pay it back. This is the LORD’s time for ·canceling what people owe [remitting debts].

3.verse: You may make a foreigner pay what is owed to you, but you must ·not collect [remit] what ·another Israelite [a relative; or a countryman; a brother] owes you.

4.verse: But there should be no ·poor [needy] people among you, because the LORD your God will richly bless you in the land he is giving you as your ·own [possession].

5.verse: He will bless you if you obey the LORD your God completely, but you must be careful to obey all the commands I am ·giving [commanding] you today.

6.verse: The LORD your God will bless you as he promised, and you will lend to other nations, but you will not need to borrow from them. You will rule over many nations, but none will rule over you.

7.verse: If there are ·poor [needy] among ·you [your relatives; or your countrymen; your brothers], in one of the ·towns [gates] of the land the LORD your God is giving you, do not be ·selfish [hard-hearted] or ·greedy [tight-fisted] toward them [Prov. 28:27; 29:7, 14].

8.verse: But ·give freely [open your hand] to them, and freely lend them whatever they need.

9.verse: Beware of ·evil [useless] thoughts. Don’t think, “The seventh year is near, the year ·to cancel what people owe [of remission].” ·You might be mean to [Your eye might be evil toward] ·the needy [your needy relative/or countryman/brother] and not give them anything. Then they will ·complain [call out] to the LORD about you, and he will find you guilty of sin.

10.verse: Give freely to the poor person, and do not ·wish that you didn’t have to give [begrudge him this matter]. The LORD your God will bless your work and everything you ·touch [undertake; send from your hand].

11.verse: There will always be poor people in the land, so I command you to ·give freely [open your hand] to your ·neighbors [or relatives; or countrymen; brothers] and to the poor and needy in your land.

12.verse: Letting Slaves Go Free - If one of your own ·people [relatives; brothers] ·sells himself [or is sold] to you as a slave, whether it is a Hebrew man or woman, that person will serve you for six years [Lev. 25:39; Neh. 5:4–5]. But in the seventh year you must let the slave go free.

13.verse: When you let slaves go, don’t send them away ·without anything [empty-handed].

14.verse: ·Give them [Provide/Outfit them with] some of your flock, your grain, and your wine, giving to them as the LORD has ·given to [blessed] you.

15.verse: Remember that you were slaves in Egypt, and the LORD your God ·saved [ransomed; redeemed] you. That is why I am commanding this to you today.

16.verse: But if your slave says to you, “I don’t want to leave you,” because he loves you and your ·family [house] and has a good life with you,

17.verse: stick an awl [a pointed tool for making holes] through his ·ear [earlobe] into the door; he will be your slave for life. Also do this to a female slave.

18.verse: Do not think of it as a hard thing when you let your slaves go free. After all, they served you six years and did twice the work of a hired person. The LORD your God will bless you in everything you do [Ex. 21:2–6; Lev. 25:39–46].

19.verse: Rules About Firstborn Animals - Save all the first male animals born to your herds and flocks [Ex. 13:2, 11–16; 22:29; Num. 18:15–18]. They are ·for [consecrated to] the LORD your God. Do not work the first calf born to your oxen, and do not cut off the wool from the first lamb born to your sheep.

20.verse: Each year you and your ·family [house] are to eat these animals in the presence of the LORD your God, in the place he will choose to be worshiped [Zion; 12:4–7].

21.verse: If an animal is crippled or blind or has ·something else wrong [some blemish/defect], do not sacrifice it to the LORD your God.

22.verse: But you may eat that animal in your own ·town [gate]. Both clean and unclean people [in a ritual sense] may eat it, as they would eat a gazelle or a deer.

23.verse: But don’t eat its blood; pour it out on the ground like water [12:24].

1.verse: The Passover - Celebrate the Passover of the LORD your God during the month of Abib [March-April], because it was during Abib that he brought you out of Egypt at night [Ex. 12:1–6; Lev. 23:5–8].

2.verse: As the sacrifice for the Passover to the LORD your God, offer an animal from your flock or herd at the place the LORD will choose to ·be worshiped [cause his name to dwell there; Zion; 12:4–7].

3.verse: Do not eat it with bread made with ·yeast [leaven]. But for seven days eat bread made without ·yeast [leaven], the bread of ·suffering [affliction], because you left Egypt in a hurry. So all your life you will remember the time you left Egypt.

4.verse: There must be no ·yeast [leaven] anywhere in your land for seven days. Offer the sacrifice on the evening of the first day, and eat all the meat before morning; do not leave it overnight.

5.verse: Do not offer the Passover sacrifice in just any ·town [gate] the LORD your God gives you,

6.verse: but offer it in the place he will choose to ·be worshiped [cause his name to dwell there; 12:4–7]. Offer it in the evening as the sun goes down, which is when you left Egypt.

7.verse: ·Roast the meat [Cook it] and eat it at the place the LORD your God will choose. The next morning go back to your tents.

8.verse: Eat bread made without ·yeast [leaven] for six days. On the seventh day have a ·special meeting [festive assembly] for the LORD your God, and do not work that day.

9.verse: The Feast of Weeks - Count seven weeks from the time you ·begin to harvest [put the sickle to] the grain,

10.verse: and then celebrate the ·Feast [Festival] of Weeks for the LORD your God [Ex. 23:16; 34:22; Lev. 23:9–21; Num. 28:26–31]. Bring an offering as a special gift to him, giving to him just as he has blessed you.

11.verse: Rejoice before the LORD your God at the place he will choose to ·be worshiped [cause his name to dwell there; 12:4–7]. Everybody should rejoice: you, your sons and daughters, your male and female servants, the Levites in your ·town [gates], the ·strangers [resident aliens], orphans, and widows living among you.

12.verse: Remember that you were slaves in Egypt, and carefully obey all these ·laws [statutes; ordinances; requirements].

13.verse: The Feast of Shelters - Celebrate the ·Feast [Festival] of ·Shelters [Booths; Tabernacles] for seven days, after you have gathered your harvest from the threshing floor and winepress [Ex. 23:16; 34:22; Lev. 23:33–36].

14.verse: Everybody should rejoice at your ·Feast [Festival]: you, your sons and daughters, your male and female servants, the Levites, ·strangers [resident aliens], orphans, and widows who live in your ·towns [gates].

15.verse: Celebrate the ·Feast [Festival] to the LORD your God for seven days at the place he will choose [v. 2; 12:4–7], because the LORD your God will bless all your ·harvest [yield; produce] and all the work ·you do [of your hands], and you will be completely happy.

16.verse: All your men must ·come [appear] before the LORD three times a year to the place he will choose [v. 2; 12:4–7]. They must come at these times: the ·Feast [Festival] of Unleavened Bread [another name for Passover], the ·Feast [Festival] of Weeks, and the ·Feast [Festival] of ·Shelters [Booths; Tabernacles]. No man should come before the LORD ·without a gift [empty-handed].

17.verse: Each of you must bring a gift that will show how much the LORD your God has blessed you.

18.verse: Judges for the People - Appoint judges and officers for your tribes in every ·town [gate] the LORD your God is giving you; they must judge the people fairly.

19.verse: Do not ·judge unfairly [distort justice] or ·take sides [show partiality/favoritism]. Do not ·let people pay you to make wrong decisions [take bribes], because ·that kind of payment [bribes] makes wise people seem blind, and it ·changes the words of good people [undermines the cause of the innocent; Ex. 23:8; Ps. 5:5; Prov. 6:35; 17:8, 23; 21:14; Eccl. 7:7].

20.verse: Do [pursue] what is ·right [righteous] so that you will live and ·always have [possess] the land the LORD your God is giving you.

21.verse: God Hates Idols - Do not set up a wooden ·Asherah idol [Asherah; 7:5; Judg. 3:7] next to the altar you build for the LORD your God,

22.verse: and do not set up holy stone pillars. The LORD your God hates them.

1.verse: If an ox or sheep has ·something wrong with it [a blemish/defect, anything wrong with it; Lev. 22:17–25], do not offer it as a sacrifice to the LORD your God. He would ·hate [detest] that.

2.verse: A man or woman in one of the ·towns [gates] the LORD gave you might be found doing something evil in the ·sight [eyes] of the LORD your God and ·breaking [transgressing] the ·Agreement [Covenant; Treaty].

3.verse: That person may have served other gods and bowed down to them or to the sun or moon or ·stars of the sky [any of the host of heaven], which I have commanded should not be done [4:19].

4.verse: If someone has told you about it, you must look into the matter carefully. If it is true that such a ·hateful [detestable; abhorrent; abominable] thing has happened in Israel,

5.verse: take the man or woman who has done the evil thing to the city gates and ·throw stones at [stone] that person until he dies.

6.verse: There must be two or three witnesses that it is true before the person is put to death; if there is only one witness, the person should not be put to death [Num. 35:30].

7.verse: The hands of the witnesses must be the first to ·throw stones at [stone] the person, and then everyone else will follow. You must get rid of the evil among you.

8.verse: Courts of Law - Some cases that come before you, ·such as murder [between one kind of bloodshed and another; intentional or unintentional], ·quarreling [between one kind of right and another], or ·attack [between one kind of assault and another; Ex. 21:18–21], may be too difficult to judge. Take these cases to the place the LORD your God will choose [12:4–7].

9.verse: Go to the priests who are Levites and to the judge who is ·on duty at that time [in office in those days]. ·Ask them about the case [Make inquiry], and they will decide.

10.verse: You must follow the decision they give you at the place the LORD your God will choose. Be careful to do everything they ·tell [teach] you.

11.verse: Follow the ·teachings [laws; instructions] they give you, and do whatever they decide, ·exactly as they tell you [you must not turn aside from the thing they tell you to the right or to the left].

12.verse: The person who ·does not show respect for [presumes not to listen to] the judge or priest who is there serving the LORD your God must be put to death. You must ·get rid of [banish; purge] that evil from Israel.

13.verse: Then everyone will hear about this and will be afraid, and they will not ·show disrespect [be presumptuous] anymore.

14.verse: Choosing a King - When you enter the land the LORD your God is giving you, taking it as your ·own [possession] and living in it, you will say, “·Let’s appoint [I will set] a king over ·us [me] like the nations all around us [1 Sam. 8:5, 20].”

15.verse: Be sure to ·appoint [set] over you the king the LORD your God chooses. He must be one of your own ·people [relatives; brothers]. Do not ·appoint [set] as your king a foreigner who is not a ·fellow Israelite [relative; brother].

16.verse: The king must not ·have too many [multiply] horses for himself [Is. 2:7–9], and he must not send people to Egypt to get more horses, because the LORD has told you, “Don’t return that way again.”

17.verse: The king must not ·have many [multiply for himself] wives, or his heart will ·be led away [turn aside] from God [1 Kin. 11:1–13]. He must not have too much silver and gold.

18.verse: When he ·becomes king [sits on the throne of his kingdom], he should write a copy of ·the teachings [these laws/instructions] on a scroll for himself, a copy taken from the priests and Levites.

19.verse: He should keep it with him all the time and read from it every day of his life. Then he will learn to ·respect [fear] the LORD his God, and he will obey all ·the teachings [these laws/instructions] and ·commands [statutes; ordinances; requirements].

20.verse: He should not ·think he is better than his fellow Israelites [exalt his heart above his relatives/brothers], and he must not ·stop obeying [turn aside from] the law ·in any way [to the right or the left] so that he and his ·descendants [sons] may rule the kingdom for a long time [2 Sam. 7:16].

1.verse: Shares for Priests and Levites - The priests are from the tribe of Levi, and that tribe will not ·receive a share of the land [have an allotment or inheritance] with the Israelites. They will eat the offerings made to the LORD by fire, which is their ·share [inheritance].

2.verse: They will not inherit any of the land like their brothers [Num. 26:62; Josh. 13:14; 14:4–5; 21], but they will inherit the LORD himself [10:9; Ex. 32:25–29; Josh. 18:7], as he has promised them.

3.verse: When you offer a bull or sheep as a sacrifice, you must share with the priests, giving them the shoulder, the ·cheeks [jowls], and the ·inner organs [stomach].

4.verse: Give them the first of your grain, new wine, and oil, as well as the first wool you cut from your sheep.

5.verse: The LORD your God has chosen the priests and their ·descendants [sons] out of all your tribes to stand and serve ·the [in the name of the] LORD ·always [all their days; 33:8–11].

6.verse: If a Levite moves from one of your ·towns [gates] anywhere in Israel where he ·lives [resides; sojourns] and comes to the place the LORD will choose [12:4–7], because ·he wants [his soul desires] to serve the LORD there,

7.verse: he may serve ·the [the name of the] LORD his God. He will be like his ·fellow [brother] Levites who ·serve [stand] there before the LORD.

8.verse: They all will have an equal share of the food. That is separate from what he has received from the sale of family possessions.

9.verse: Do Not Follow Other Nations - When you enter the land the LORD your God is giving you, don’t learn to do the ·hateful [detestable; abhorrent; abominable] things the other nations do.

10.verse: Don’t let anyone among you offer a son or daughter as a sacrifice in the fire [12:30–31]. Don’t let anyone use ·magic [divination; Ex. 7:11; Ezek. 21:21] or witchcraft, or ·try to explain the meaning of signs [augury or sorcery].

11.verse: Don’t let anyone ·try to control others with magic [cast spells], and don’t let them ·be mediums [consult/inquire of ghosts or spirits] or try to ·talk with the spirits of [consult] dead people [1 Sam. 28].

12.verse: The LORD ·hates [detests] anyone who does these things. Because the other nations do these things, the LORD your God will ·force [dispossess] them out of the land ahead of you.

13.verse: But you must be ·innocent [blameless] in the presence of the LORD your God.

14.verse: The Lord’s Special Prophet - The nations you will ·force out [dispossess] listen to people who use ·magic [divination] and witchcraft, but the LORD your God will not let you do those things.

15.verse: The LORD your God will ·give [raise up for] you a prophet like me, who is one of your own ·people [relatives; brothers; ultimately Jesus]. Listen to him [Acts 3:25–26; 7:37].

16.verse: This is what you asked the LORD your God to do when you were ·gathered [assembled] at ·Mount Sinai [Horeb; 1:6]. You said, “Don’t make ·us [me] listen to the voice of the LORD ·our [my] God again, and don’t make ·us [me] look at this ·terrible [great] fire anymore, or ·we [I] will die [5:23–27].”

17.verse: So the LORD said to me, “What they have said is good.

18.verse: So I will ·give [raise up for] them a prophet like you, who is one of their own ·people [relatives; brothers]. I will ·tell him what to say [put my words in his mouth], and he will tell them everything I command.

19.verse: This prophet will speak for me; anyone who does not listen when he speaks in my name will ·answer [be accountable] to me.

20.verse: But if a prophet ·says something I did not tell him to say as though he were speaking for me [speaks presumptuously in my name a word I did not command him to speak], or if a prophet speaks in the name of other gods, that prophet must be killed [Jer. 28:15–17].”

21.verse: You might be ·thinking [saying in your heart/mind], “How can we know if a message is not from the LORD?”

22.verse: If what a prophet says in the name of the LORD does not happen, it is not the LORD’s message. That prophet was speaking ·his own ideas [presumptuously]. Don’t be afraid of him.

1.verse: Cities of Safety - When the LORD your God gives you land that belongs to the other nations, nations that he will ·destroy [cut off], you will ·force them out [dispossess them] and live in their cities and houses.

2.verse: Then ·choose [set apart; separate] three cities in the middle of the land the LORD your God is giving you as your ·own [possession].

3.verse: ·Build roads to these cities [or Work out the distances], and divide the land the LORD is giving you into three parts so that someone who kills another person may run to ·these cities [there].

4.verse: This is the rule for someone who kills another person and runs to one of these cities in order to save his life [Ex. 21:13–14; Num. 35:6–34; Josh. 20]. But the person must have killed a neighbor ·without meaning to [accidentally; unintentionally], not out of hatred.

5.verse: For example, suppose someone goes into the forest with a neighbor to cut wood and swings an ax to cut down a tree. If the ax head ·flies [slips] off the handle, ·hitting and killing [finds] the neighbor, the one who killed him may run to one of these cities to save his life.

6.verse: Otherwise, the ·dead person’s relative who has the duty of punishing a murderer [near-kinsman; avenger of blood] might be angry and chase him. If the city is far away, the relative might ·catch [pursue and overtake] and kill the person, even though he should not be killed because there was no intent to kill his neighbor.

7.verse: This is why I command you to ·choose [set apart; separate] these three cities.

8.verse: Carefully obey all these laws I’m ·giving [commanding] you today. Love the LORD your God, and always do what he wants you to do. Then the LORD your God will enlarge your ·land [boundaries] as he ·promised [swore to] your ·ancestors [fathers], giving you the whole land he promised to them. After that, ·choose three more cities of safety [add three more cities to these three]

9.verse: Carefully obey all these laws I’m ·giving [commanding] you today. Love the LORD your God, and always do what he wants you to do. Then the LORD your God will enlarge your ·land [boundaries] as he ·promised [swore to] your ·ancestors [fathers], giving you the whole land he promised to them. After that, ·choose three more cities of safety [add three more cities to these three]

10.verse: so that innocent ·people will not be killed [blood will not be shed] in your land, the land that the LORD your God is giving you as your ·own [inheritance]. ·By doing this you will not be guilty of allowing the death of innocent people […bringing bloodguilt on you].

11.verse: But if a person hates his neighbor and, after ·hiding and waiting [lying in wait], ·attacks [rises up] and ·kills [strikes] him and then runs to one of these cities for safety,

12.verse: the elders of his own city should send for the murderer. They should bring the person back from the city of safety and hand him over to the ·relative who has the duty of punishing the murderer [near-kinsman; avenger of blood].

13.verse: ·Show no mercy [Do not let your eyes show compassion on him]. You must ·remove [banish; purge] from Israel the ·guilt of murdering [blood of] innocent people so that things will go well for you.

14.verse: Do not move the ·stone that marks the border [boundary marker] of your neighbor’s land, which people long ago set in place [27:17; Job 24:2–4; Prov. 23:10–11; Hos. 5:10]. It marks what you inherit in the land the LORD your God is giving you as your ·own [possession].

15.verse: Rules About Witnesses - One witness is not enough to accuse a person of a crime or sin. A case must be proved by two or three witnesses [17:6; Num. 35:30].

16.verse: If a witness ·lies [is malicious/unjust] and accuses a person of a crime,

17.verse: the two people who are arguing must stand in the presence of the LORD before the priests and judges who are ·on duty [in office in those days].

18.verse: The judges must check the matter carefully. The witness who is a liar, lying about a ·fellow Israelite [relative; brother],

19.verse: must be punished. He must be punished in the same way the ·other person [relative; brother] would have been punished. You must ·get rid of [banish; purge] the evil among you.

20.verse: The rest of the people will hear about this and be afraid, and no one among you will ever do such an evil thing again.

21.verse: ·Show no mercy [Do not let your eyes show compassion on him]. A life must be paid for a life, an eye for an eye, a tooth for a tooth, a hand for a hand, a foot for a foot [Ex. 21:24–25; Lev. 24:17–20].

1.verse: Laws for War - When you go to war against your enemies and you see horses and chariots and an army that is bigger than yours, don’t be afraid of them. The LORD your God, who brought you out of Egypt, will be with you.

2.verse: The priest must ·come [approach] and speak to the army before you ·go into [engage in] battle.

3.verse: He will say, “Listen, Israel! Today you are going into battle against your enemies. Don’t lose ·your courage [heart] or be afraid. Don’t panic or be ·frightened [in dread],

4.verse: because the LORD your God goes with you, to fight for you against your enemies and to ·save you [give you the victory].”

5.verse: The ·officers [or scribes] should say to the army, “·Has anyone [Who has] built a new house but not ·given it to God [dedicated it]? He may go home, because he might die in battle and someone else would ·get to give his house to God [dedicate it].

6.verse: ·Has anyone [Who has] planted a vineyard and not begun to enjoy it? He may go home, because he might die in battle and someone else would enjoy his vineyard.

7.verse: ·Is any man [Who is] engaged to a woman and not yet married to her? He may go home, because he might die in battle and someone else would marry her.”

8.verse: Then the ·officers [or scribes] should also say, “Is anyone here afraid? Has anyone lost ·his courage [heart]? He may go home so that he will not ·cause others to lose their courage, too [melt the hearts of his relatives/brothers like his heart].”

9.verse: When the ·officers [scribes] finish speaking to the army, they should appoint commanders to lead it.

10.verse: When you march up to attack a city, first make them an offer of peace.

11.verse: If they accept your offer and open their gates to you, all the people of that city will ·become your slaves and work for you [serve you in forced labor].

12.verse: But if they do not make peace with you and fight you in battle, you should ·surround [besiege] that city.

13.verse: The LORD your God will give it ·to you [into your hands]. Then ·kill [strike] all the men with your swords,

14.verse: and you may take ·everything else [all the plunder] in the city for yourselves. Take the women, children, and animals, and you may use ·these things [the plunder] the LORD your God gives you from your enemies.

15.verse: Do this to all the cities that are far away, that do not belong to the nations nearby.

16.verse: But ·leave nothing alive [do not let anything that breathes live] in the cities of the land the LORD your God is giving you as an inheritance.

17.verse: ·Completely destroy [Devote to the LORD; Josh. 6:17] these people: the Hittites, Amorites, Canaanites, Perizzites, Hivites, and Jebusites, as the LORD your God has commanded.

18.verse: Otherwise, they will teach you what they do for their gods, and if you do these ·hateful [detestable; abhorrent; abominable] things, you will sin against the LORD your God.

19.verse: If you ·surround [besiege] and attack a city for ·a long time [many days], trying to capture it, do not destroy its trees with an ax. You can eat the fruit from the trees, but do not cut them down. ·These trees are not the enemy, so don’t make war against them [Are these trees of the field human that you should go against them in siege?].

20.verse: But you may cut down trees that you know are not fruit trees and use them to build devices to attack the city walls, until the city is captured.

1.verse: A Person Found Murdered - Suppose ·someone is found murdered [a corpse], lying in a field in the land the LORD your God is giving you as your ·own [possession], and no one knows who ·killed [struck] the person.

2.verse: Your elders and judges should go to where the ·body [corpse] was found, and they should measure how far it is to the nearby cities.

3.verse: The elders of the city nearest the body must take a ·young cow [heifer] that has never worked or ·worn [pulled] a yoke,

4.verse: and they must lead her down to a ·valley [wadi] that has never been plowed or planted, with a ·stream [wadi] flowing through it. There they must break the ·young cow’s [heifer’s] neck.

5.verse: The priests, the sons of Levi, should come forward, because they have been chosen by the LORD your God to serve him and to give blessings in the LORD’s name. They are the ones who decide cases of ·quarreling [accusation] and attacks.

6.verse: Then all the elders of the city nearest the ·murdered person [corpse] should wash their hands over the ·young cow [heifer] whose neck was broken in the ·valley [wadi].

7.verse: They should declare: “·We did not kill this person [Our hands did not spill this blood], and ·we [our eyes] did not see it happen.

8.verse: LORD, ·remove this sin from [make atonement for] your people Israel, whom you have ·saved [redeemed; ransomed]. Don’t ·blame your people, the Israelites, for the murder of this innocent person [place the guilt of innocent blood in the midst of your people Israel].” And so the murder will be ·paid [atoned] for.

9.verse: Then you will have ·removed [banished; purged] from yourselves the guilt of ·murdering an innocent person [innocent blood], because you will be doing what ·the LORD says is right [is right/virtuous in the eyes of the LORD].

10.verse: Captive Women as Wives - When you go to war against your enemies, the LORD will ·help you defeat them [give them into your hands] so you will take them captive.

11.verse: If you see a beautiful woman among the captives and ·are attracted to [desire; fall in love with] her, you may take her as your wife.

12.verse: Bring her into your home, where she must shave her head and cut her nails

13.verse: and change the clothes she was wearing when you captured her. After she has lived in your house and cried for her ·parents [father and her mother] for a month, you may marry her. You will be her husband, and she will be your wife.

14.verse: But if you are not pleased with her, you must let her go anywhere she wants. You must not sell her for money or make her a slave, because you have ·taken away her honor [humiliated; exploited her].

15.verse: The Oldest Son - A man might have two wives, one he loves and one he ·doesn’t [hates; dislikes]. Both wives might have sons by him. If the ·older son [firstborn] belongs to the wife he ·does not love [hates; dislikes],

16.verse: when that man wills his property to his sons he must not give the son of the wife he loves what belongs to the ·older [firstborn] son, the son of the wife he ·does not love [hates; dislikes].

17.verse: He must agree to give the ·older son [firstborn] two shares of everything he owns, even though the ·older son [firstborn] is from the wife he does ·not love [hates; dislikes]. That son was the first ·to prove his father could have children [of his virility], so he has the rights that belong to the ·older son [firstborn].

18.verse: Sons Who Refuse to Obey - If someone has a son who is stubborn, who ·turns [rebels] against his father and mother and doesn’t obey them or listen when they ·correct [discipline] him,

19.verse: his ·parents [mother and his father] must ·take [grab] him to the elders at the city gate [Ex. 21:15; Lev. 20:9].

20.verse: They will say to the elders, “Our son is stubborn and ·turns [rebels] against us. He will not obey us. He ·eats too much [is a glutton], and he is ·always drunk [a drunk].”

21.verse: Then all the men in his town must ·throw stones at [stone] him until he dies. ·Get rid of [Banish; Purge] the evil among you, because then all the people of Israel will hear about this and be afraid.

22.verse: Other Laws - If someone is guilty of a sin worthy of death, he must be put to death and his body ·displayed [hung] on a tree.

23.verse: But don’t leave his body hanging on the tree overnight; be sure to bury him that same day, because anyone whose body is displayed on a tree is cursed by God [Matt. 27:57–58; Gal. 3:13]. You must not ruin the land the LORD your God is giving you as your ·own [inheritance].

1.verse: If you see your ·fellow Israelite’s [relative’s; brother’s] ox or sheep wandering away, don’t ignore it. Take it back to ·its owner [your relative/brother; Ex. 23:4–5].

2.verse: If ·the owner [your relative/brother] does not live close to you, or if you do not know who the owner is, take the animal home with you. Keep it until ·the owner [your relative/brother] comes looking for it; then give it back.

3.verse: Do the same thing if you find a donkey or ·coat [cloak; garment] or anything someone lost. Don’t just ignore it.

4.verse: If you see your ·fellow Israelite’s [relative’s; brother’s] donkey or ox fallen on the road, don’t ignore it. Help the owner get it up.

5.verse: A woman must not wear men’s ·clothes [apparel; items], and a man must not wear women’s clothes. The LORD your God ·hates [detests] anyone who does that.

6.verse: If you find a bird’s nest by the road, either in a tree or on the ground, and the mother bird is sitting on the young birds or eggs, do not take the mother bird with the young birds.

7.verse: You may take the young birds, but you must let the mother bird go free. Then things will go well for you, and you will live a long time.

8.verse: When you build a new house, build a ·low wall around the edge of [a fence/parapet on] the roof [the flat roofs of Israelite houses were used for living space] so you will not ·be guilty [have bloodguilt] if someone falls off the roof [to avoid negligent homicide].

9.verse: Don’t plant two different kinds of seeds in your vineyard. Otherwise, ·both crops will be ruined [the fullness will be forfeit, both the seed that has been sown as well as the produce of the vineyard; to avoid unnatural combinations, perhaps as a reminder that Israelites were to be separate from Gentiles, see also vv. 10–11].

10.verse: Don’t plow with an ox and a donkey tied together.

11.verse: Don’t wear clothes made of wool and linen woven together.

12.verse: Tie several pieces of thread together; then put these tassels on the four corners of your coat [perhaps to weigh down the garment to avoid exposure].

13.verse: Marriage Laws - If a man marries a girl and has sexual relations with her but then decides he ·does not like [hates] her,

14.verse: he might ·talk badly about her [charge her with wanton behavior] and give her a bad name. He might say, “I married this woman, but when I ·had sexual relations with [approached] her, I did not find that she was a virgin.”

15.verse: Then the girl’s ·parents [father and mother] must bring ·proof [evidence] that she was a virgin to the elders at the city gate.

16.verse: The girl’s father will say to the elders, “I gave my daughter to this man to be his wife, but now he ·does not want [hates] her.

17.verse: This man has ·told lies about my daughter [charged my daughter with wanton behavior]. He has said, ‘I did not find your daughter to be a virgin,’ but here is the ·proof [evidence] that my daughter was a virgin.” Then her parents are to show the sheet [blood-stained, showing she had been a virgin] to the elders of the city,

18.verse: and the elders must take the man and ·punish [discipline] him.

19.verse: They must make him pay about ·two and one-half pounds [one hundred shekels] of silver to the girl’s father, because the man has given an Israelite virgin a bad name. The girl will continue to be the man’s wife, and he may not divorce her as long as he lives.

20.verse: But if ·the things the husband said about his wife are [this word/charge is] true, and there is no ·proof [evidence] that she was a virgin,

21.verse: the girl must be brought to the door of her father’s house. Then the men of the town must put her to death by ·throwing stones at [stoning] her. She has done a ·disgraceful [shameful] thing in Israel by ·having sexual relations before she was married [acting like a prostitute in the house of her father]. You must ·get rid of [banish; purge] the evil among you.

22.verse: If a man is found ·having sexual relations [lying] with another man’s wife, both the woman and the man who ·had sexual relations [lay] with her must die. ·Get rid of [Banish; Purge] this evil from Israel.

23.verse: If a man meets a virgin in a city and ·has sexual relations [lies] with her, but she is engaged to another man,

24.verse: you must take both of them to the city gate and ·put them to death by throwing stones at [stone] them. Kill the girl, because she was in a city and did not scream for help. And kill the man for having sexual relations with ·another man’s wife [the wife of his neighbor/friend]. You must ·get rid of [banish; purge] the evil among you.

25.verse: But if a man meets an engaged girl out in the ·country [field] and ·forces her to have sexual relations with him [seizes her and lies with her], only the man who ·had sexual relations [lay] with her must be put to death.

26.verse: Don’t do anything to the girl, because she has not done a sin worthy of death. This is like the person who ·attacks [rises up] and murders a neighbor;

27.verse: the man found the engaged girl in the ·country [field] and she ·screamed [yelled for help], but no one was there to ·save [rescue] her.

28.verse: If a man meets a virgin who is not engaged to be married and ·forces her to have sexual relations with him [grabs her and lies with her] and ·people find out about it [is discovered],

29.verse: the man who ·had sexual relations [lay] with her must pay the girl’s father about ·one and one-fourth pounds [fifty shekels] of silver. He must also marry the girl, because he has ·dishonored [humiliated; raped] her, and he may never divorce her for as long as he lives [Ex. 22:16–17].

30.verse: A man must not marry his father’s wife; he must not ·dishonor his father in this way [uncover his father’s skirt; Lev. 18:7–8; 20:11].

1.verse: The Lord’s People - No man who has had ·part of his sex organ [his testicles crushed or his penis] cut off may come into the ·meeting to worship [assembly of] the LORD [Acts 8:26–40].

2.verse: No one born ·to parents who were forbidden by law to marry [of a forbidden marriage] may come into the ·meeting to worship [assembly of] the LORD. The descendants for ten generations may not come in either.

3.verse: No Ammonite or Moabite may come into the ·meeting to worship [assembly of] the LORD, and none of their descendants for ten generations may come in.

4.verse: This is because the Ammonites and Moabites did not give you bread and water when you came out of Egypt. And they hired Balaam son of Beor, from Pethor in Northwest Mesopotamia, to put a curse on you [Num. 22–24].

5.verse: But the LORD your God would not listen to Balaam. He ·turned [transformed; overturned] the curse into a blessing for you, because the LORD your God loves you.

6.verse: Don’t ·wish for [seek] their peace or ·success [prosperity] as long as you live.

7.verse: Don’t ·hate [detest] Edomites; they are your ·close relatives [brothers; descendants of Esau the brother of Jacob/Israel]. Don’t ·hate [detest] Egyptians, because you were ·foreigners [resident aliens] in their country [during the time of Joseph, God’s people survived a famine in Egypt; Gen. 41–42].

8.verse: ·The great-grandchildren of these two peoples [their children to the third generation] may come into the ·meeting to worship [assembly of] the LORD.

9.verse: Keeping the Camp Clean - When you are camped ·in time of war [against your enemies], keep away from ·unclean things [foulness; a bad/evil thing; referring to ritual uncleanness].

10.verse: If a man becomes unclean during the night, he must go outside the camp and not come back [referring to an emission of semen; Lev. 15:16].

11.verse: But when evening comes, he must wash himself, and at sunset he may come back into the camp.

12.verse: Choose a place outside the camp where people may go ·to relieve themselves [outside].

13.verse: ·Carry a tent peg with you [As part of your equipment have a tent peg/or trowel with you], and when you ·relieve yourself [squat; sit], dig a hole and cover up your ·dung [excrement].

14.verse: The LORD your God ·moves [walks] around through your camp to protect you and to defeat your enemies for you, so the camp must be holy. He must not see anything ·unclean [indecent] among you so that he will not leave you.

15.verse: Other Laws - If an escaped slave comes to you, do not hand over the slave to his master.

16.verse: Let the slave live with you anywhere he likes, in any ·town [gate] he chooses. Do not ·mistreat [oppress; exploit] him.

17.verse: No Israelite ·man [son] or ·woman [daughter] must ever become a ·temple [sacred] prostitute.

18.verse: Do not bring ·a male or female prostitute’s pay [the pay of a prostitute or the price of a “dog”; “dog” is probably a reference to a male temple prostitute] to the ·Temple [house] of the LORD your God to pay what you have ·promised [vowed] to the LORD, because the LORD your God ·hates [detests] ·prostitution [both of them; male and female temple prostitution].

19.verse: If you loan your ·fellow Israelites [relatives; brothers] money or food or anything else, don’t make them pay back ·more than you loaned them [interest; Ex. 22:25; Lev. 25:36–37].

20.verse: You may charge foreigners, but not ·fellow Israelites [your relatives/brothers]. Then the LORD your God will bless ·everything you do [your undertakings; all that is sent out from your hand] in the land you are entering to ·take as your own [possess].

21.verse: If you make a ·promise [vow] to give ·something [a vow] to the LORD your God [Lev. 7:16–17; Num. 30:2–17], do not ·be slow [delay] to pay it, because the LORD your God ·demands [will surely seek] it from you. Do not be guilty of sin.

22.verse: But if you do not make the ·promise [vow], you will not be guilty.

23.verse: You must do whatever ·you say you will do [comes out of your lips], because you ·chose to make [freely made with your own mouth] the ·promise [vow] to the LORD your God [Eccl. 5:4–5].

24.verse: If you go into your neighbor’s vineyard, you may eat as many grapes as you wish, but do not put any grapes into your basket.

25.verse: If you go into your neighbor’s grainfield, you may pick grain with your hands, but you must not cut down your neighbor’s grain with your sickle.

1.verse: A man might marry a woman but later decide she doesn’t ·please him [find favor in his eyes] because he has found something ·bad [indecent; objectionable] about her. He writes out divorce papers for her, ·gives them to her [places them in her hand], and sends her away from his house.

2.verse: After she leaves his house, she goes and marries another man,

3.verse: but her second husband ·does not like her either [hates her]. So he writes out divorce papers for her, ·gives them to her [places them in her hand], and sends her away from his house. Or the second husband might die.

4.verse: In either case, her first husband who divorced her must not marry her again, because she has become ·unclean [in a ritual sense]. The LORD would ·hate [detest] this. Don’t bring this sin into the land the LORD your God is giving you as your ·own [inheritance; Matt. 5:31–32; 19:3–9].

5.verse: A man who has just married must not be sent ·to war [with the army] or be given any other duty. He should be free to stay home for a year to make his new wife happy [20:7].

6.verse: If someone owes you ·something [a pledge], do not take his two stones for grinding grain—not even the upper one—·in place of what he owes [as a pledge], ·because this is how the person makes a living [that would be taking a person’s life as a pledge].

7.verse: If someone ·kidnaps a fellow Israelite [is found stealing one of his brothers from among the sons/children of Israel], either to make him a slave or sell him, the ·kidnapper [robber] must be killed. You must ·get rid of [banish; purge] the evil among you [Ex. 21:16].

8.verse: Be careful when someone has a ·skin disease [leprosy; the term does not refer to modern leprosy (Hansen’s disease), but to various skin disorders; Lev. 13:2]. Do exactly what the priests, the Levites, teach you, being careful to do what I have commanded them.

9.verse: Remember what the LORD your God did to Miriam on your way out of Egypt [Num. 12:10].

10.verse: When you make a loan to your neighbors, don’t go into their homes to get ·something in place of it [a pledge].

11.verse: Stay outside and let them go in and get what they ·promised [pledged to] you.

12.verse: If a poor person gives you a ·coat to show he will pay the loan back [pledge], don’t keep it overnight.

13.verse: Give the ·coat [pledge] back at sunset, because your neighbor needs that coat to sleep in, and he will ·be grateful to [bless] you. And the LORD your God will see that you have done a ·good [righteous] thing.

14.verse: Don’t ·cheat [oppress; exploit] hired servants who are poor and needy, whether they are ·fellow Israelites [relatives; brothers] or ·foreigners [resident aliens] living in one of your ·towns [gates].

15.verse: Pay them each day before sunset, because they are poor and need the money. Otherwise, they may ·complain [cry out] to the LORD about you, and you will be guilty of sin.

16.verse: ·Parents [Fathers] must not be put to death if their children do wrong, and children must not be put to death if their ·parents [fathers] do wrong. Each person must die for his own sin [Jer. 31:29–30; Ezek. 18:1–4].

17.verse: Do not be unfair to a ·foreigner [resident alien] or an orphan. Don’t take a widow’s coat ·to make sure she pays you back [as a pledge; 24:10–13].

18.verse: Remember that you were slaves in Egypt, and the LORD your God ·saved [ransomed; redeemed] you from there. That is why I am commanding you to do this.

19.verse: When you are ·gathering [reaping] your harvest in the field and ·leave behind [forget] a bundle of grain, don’t go back and get it. Leave it there for ·foreigners [resident aliens], orphans, and widows so that the LORD your God can bless everything you do [Ruth 2].

20.verse: When you beat your olive trees to knock the olives off, don’t ·beat the trees a second time. Leave […strip] what is left for ·foreigners [resident aliens], orphans, and widows.

21.verse: When you harvest the grapes in your vineyard, don’t ·pick the vines a second time [glean what is left]. Leave what is left for foreigners [resident aliens], orphans, and widows.

22.verse: Remember that you were slaves in Egypt; that is why I am commanding you to do this [Ex. 23:11; Lev. 19:9–10; 23:22].

1.verse: If two people have an argument and go to court, the judges will decide the case. They will ·declare one person right [acquit the innocent] and ·the other [convict the] guilty.

2.verse: If the guilty person has to be ·punished with a beating [struck; flogged], the judge will make that person lie down and be ·beaten [struck; flogged] in front of him. The number of lashes should match the crime.

3.verse: But don’t ·hit [strike] a person more than forty times, because more than that would disgrace ·him [your relative/neighbor] before others [2 Cor. 11:24].

4.verse: When an ox is ·working in the grain [treading the grain], do not ·cover its mouth to keep it from eating [muzzle it; 1 Cor. 9:9].

5.verse: If two brothers are living together, and one of them dies without having a son, his widow must not marry ·someone [a stranger] outside her husband’s family. Her husband’s brother must marry her, which is his duty to her as a brother-in-law.

6.verse: The first son she has ·counts as the son of the dead [will raise up the name of his] brother so that his name will not be ·forgotten [blotted/wiped out] in Israel [Gen. 38; Ruth 4].

7.verse: But if a man does not want to marry his brother’s widow, she should go to the elders at the town gate. She should say, “My brother-in-law will not ·carry on [raise up] his brother’s name in Israel. He refuses to do his duty for me.”

8.verse: Then the elders of the town must call for the man and talk to him. But if he ·is stubborn [stands] and says, “I don’t want to marry her,”

9.verse: the woman must go up to him in ·front of the leaders [the presence of the elders]. She must take off one of his sandals and spit in his face and say, “This is for the man who won’t ·continue [build] his brother’s ·family [house]!”

10.verse: Then that man’s ·family [house] shall be known in Israel as the ·Family [House] of the Unsandaled.

11.verse: If two men are fighting and one man’s wife comes to ·save [protect] her husband from his attacker, grabbing the attacker by his ·sex organs [genitals],

12.verse: you must cut off her hand. ·Show her no mercy [Do not let your eyes show compassion on her].

13.verse: Don’t carry two ·sets of weights [stones] ·with you [in your bag/pouch], one heavy and one light.

14.verse: Don’t have two different sets of measures in your house, one large and one small.

15.verse: You must have ·true [whole; full] and ·honest [accurate] weights and measures so that you will live a long time in the land the LORD your God is giving you.

16.verse: The LORD your God ·hates [detests] anyone who ·is dishonest and uses dishonest measures [does such things—who acts crookedly/does bad things; Lev. 19:35–37; Prov. 11:1; Ezek. 45:10–12; Amos 8:5; Mic. 6:10–12].

17.verse: Remember what the Amalekites did to you when you came out of Egypt [Ex. 17:8–16].

18.verse: When you were tired and worn out, they met you on the road and ·attacked [picked off] all ·those lagging behind [the stragglers]. They were not afraid of God.

19.verse: When the LORD your God gives you rest from all the enemies around you in the land he ·is giving you [makes you inherit] as your ·own [possession], you shall ·destroy [blot/wipe out] any memory of the Amalekites ·on the earth [from under the heavens]. Do not forget [Saul forgot (1 Sam. 15), but the Amalekites (called Agagites) come to an end in the book of Esther (Esth. 3:1)]!

1.verse: The First Harvest - When you go into the land the LORD your God is giving you as your ·own [inheritance], to ·take it over [possess it] and live in it,

2.verse: you must take some of the first harvest of crops that grow from the land the LORD your God is giving you. Put the food in a basket and go to the place where the LORD your God will choose to ·be worshiped [cause his name to dwell; Zion; 12:4–6].

3.verse: Go and say to the priest ·on duty at that time [in office in those days], “Today I declare before the LORD your God that I have come into the land the LORD promised our ·ancestors [fathers] that he would give us [Gen. 12:1–3].”

4.verse: The priest will take your basket and set it down in front of the altar of the LORD your God.

5.verse: Then you shall announce before the LORD your God: “My father was a wandering Aramean [likely a reference to Jacob/Israel’s stay in Paddan-Aram; Gen. 28–31]. He went down to Egypt and lived as a ·foreigner [resident alien] with only a few people, but they became a great, powerful, and large nation there [Gen. 12:1–3].

6.verse: But the Egyptians were ·cruel [mean] to us, ·making us suffer [afflicting/humiliating us] and ·work very hard [giving us onerous work].

7.verse: So we ·prayed [cried out] to the LORD, the God of our ·ancestors [fathers], and he heard us. When he saw our ·trouble [affliction; humiliation], hard work, and ·suffering [oppression; Ex. 2:23–25; 3:7, 9],

8.verse: the LORD brought us out of Egypt with his ·great power [strong hand] and ·strength [outstretched arm], using great terrors, signs, and ·miracles [wonders].

9.verse: Then he brought us to this place and gave us this ·fertile land [land flowing with milk and honey; Ex. 3:8].

10.verse: Now I bring part of the first harvest from this land that you, LORD, have given me.” Place the basket before the LORD your God and bow down before him.

11.verse: Then you and the Levites and ·foreigners [resident aliens] among you should rejoice, because the LORD your God has given good things to you and your ·family [house].

12.verse: ·Bring [Finish paying] a ·tenth [tithe] of all your harvest the third year [14:28–29] (the year to give a ·tenth [tithe] of your harvest). Give it to the Levites, ·foreigners [resident aliens], orphans, and widows so that they may eat in your ·towns [gates] and be full.

13.verse: Then say to the LORD your God, “I have taken out of my house ·the part of my harvest that belongs to God [what is holy/consecrated/sacred], and I have given it to the Levites, ·foreigners [resident aliens], orphans, and widows. I have done everything you commanded me; I have not broken your commands, and I have not forgotten any of them.

14.verse: I have not eaten any of the holy part while I was in ·sorrow [mourning]. I have not removed any of it while I was unclean [in a ritual sense], and I have not offered it ·for [or to] dead people. I have obeyed you, the LORD my God, and have done everything you commanded me.

15.verse: So look down from heaven, your holy home. Bless your people Israel and bless the land you have given us, which you ·promised [swore] to our ·ancestors [fathers]—a ·fertile land [land flowing with milk and honey; Ex. 3:8].”

16.verse: Obey the Lord’s Commands - Today the LORD your God commands you to obey all these ·rules [statutes; ordinances; requirements] and laws; be careful to obey them with ·your whole being [all your heart/mind and all your soul].

17.verse: Today you have said that the LORD is your God, and you ·have promised to do what he wants you to do [will walk on his way/path]—to keep his ·rules [statutes; ordinances; requirements], commands, and laws. You have said you will ·obey him [listen to his voice].

18.verse: And today the LORD has said that you are his ·very own people [treasured/special possession; Ex. 19:5], as he has promised you. But you must obey his commands.

19.verse: He will ·make you greater [set you higher] than all the other nations he made. He will give you praise, fame, and honor, and you will be a holy people to the LORD your God, as he has said [Ex. 19:6].

5.verse: Build an altar of stones there to the LORD your God, but don’t use any iron tool to cut the stones [Ex. 20:25];

6.verse: build the altar of the LORD your God with ·stones from the field [uncut stones; whole stones]. Offer burnt offerings [Lev. 1:1–17] on it to the LORD your God,

7.verse: and offer ·fellowship [or peace; well-being] offerings [Lev. 3:1] there, and eat them and rejoice before the LORD your God.

8.verse: Then write clearly all the words of these ·teachings [laws; instructions] on the stones.”

9.verse: Curses of the Law - Then Moses and the Levites who were priests spoke to all Israel and said, “Be ·quiet [silent], Israel. Listen! Today you have become the people of the LORD your God.

10.verse: ·Obey [Listen to the voice of] the LORD your God, and keep his commands and ·laws [statutes; ordinances; requirements] that I ·give [command] you today.”

11.verse: That day Moses also gave the people this command:

12.verse: When you cross the Jordan River, these tribes must stand on Mount Gerizim to bless the people: Simeon, Levi, Judah, Issachar, Joseph and Benjamin.

13.verse: And these tribes must stand on Mount Ebal to announce the curses: Reuben, Gad, Asher, Zebulun, Dan, and Naphtali [these two mountains form a natural amphitheatre].

14.verse: The Levites will say to all the people of Israel in a loud voice:

15.verse: “Anyone will be cursed who makes an idol or statue and secretly sets it up, because the LORD ·hates [detests] the ·idols people make [the work of the hand of an artisan; 5:8–10; Ex. 20:3–5; 34:17; Is. 44:9–20].” Then all the people will say, “Amen!”

16.verse: “Anyone will be cursed who dishonors his father or mother [5:16; Ex. 20:12; 21:17; Lev. 20:9].” Then all the people will say, “Amen!”

17.verse: “Anyone will be cursed who moves ·the stone that marks a neighbor’s border [a neighbor’s boundary marker; 19:14; Job 24:2–4; Prov. 23:10–11; Hos. 5:10].” Then all the people will say, “Amen!”

18.verse: “Anyone will be cursed who ·sends [misleads] a blind person down the wrong road [Lev. 19:14].” Then all the people will say, “Amen!”

19.verse: “Anyone will be cursed who is ·unfair [deprives justice] to ·foreigners [resident aliens], orphans, or widows.” Then all the people will say, “Amen!”

20.verse: “A man will be cursed who ·has sexual relations [lies] with his father’s wife, because it ·is a dishonor to [uncovers the skirt of; Lev. 18:7–8; 20:11] his father.” Then all the people will say, “Amen!”

21.verse: “Anyone will be cursed who ·has sexual relations [lies] with an animal [Ex. 22:19; Lev. 18:23; 20:15].” Then all the people will say, “Amen!”

22.verse: “A man will be cursed who ·has sexual relations [lies] with his sister, whether she is his father’s daughter or his mother’s daughter [Lev. 18:9, 11; 20:17].” Then all the people will say, “Amen!”

23.verse: “A man will be cursed who ·has sexual relations [lies] with his mother-in-law [Lev. 18:17; 20:14].” Then all the people will say, “Amen!”

24.verse: “Anyone will be cursed who ·kills [strikes] a neighbor secretly.” Then all the people will say, “Amen!”

25.verse: “Anyone will be cursed who takes ·money [a bribe] to ·murder [strike] an innocent person [Ex. 23:8].” Then all the people will say, “Amen!”

26.verse: “Anyone will be cursed who does not ·agree with [confirm] the words of these ·teachings [laws; instructions] and does not obey them.” Then all the people will say, “Amen!”

1.verse: Blessings for Obeying - You must completely ·obey [listen to the voice of] the LORD your God, and you must carefully follow all his commands I am ·giving [commanding] you today. Then the LORD your God will ·make you greater [set you higher] than any other nation on earth.

2.verse: ·Obey [Listen to the voice of] the LORD your God so that all these blessings will come and ·stay with [overtake] you:

4.verse: ·Your children [The fruit of your womb] will be blessed, as well as ·your crops [the fruit of your land]; your ·herds [the fruit of your livestock] will be blessed with calves and your flocks with lambs.

5.verse: Your basket and your ·kitchen [kneading bowl] will be blessed.

6.verse: You will be blessed when you come in and when you go out.

7.verse: The LORD will help you defeat the enemies that ·come [rise against you] to fight you. They will attack you from one direction, but they will run from you in seven directions [as at Jericho; Josh. 6–7].

10.verse: Then everyone on earth will see that you are ·the LORD’s people [called by the name of the LORD], and they will be afraid of you.

11.verse: The LORD will make you rich: ·You will have many children, your animals will have many young, and your land will give good crops […in the fruit of your womb, in the fruit of your livestock, and in the fruit of your land]. It is the land that the LORD ·promised [swore to] your ·ancestors [fathers] he would give to you [Gen. 12:1–3].

14.verse: Do not ·disobey [turn aside to the right or to the left from] anything I command you today. Do exactly as I command, and do not follow other gods or serve them.

15.verse: Curses for Disobeying - But if you do not ·obey [listen to the voice of] the LORD your God and carefully follow all his commands and ·laws [statutes; ordinances; requirements] I am ·giving [commanding] you today, all these curses will come upon you and ·stay [overtake you]:

17.verse: Your basket and your ·kitchen [kneading bowl] will be cursed.

18.verse: ·Your children [The fruit of your womb] will be cursed, as well as ·your crops [the fruit of your land]; the calves of your herds and the lambs of your flocks will be cursed.

28.verse: The LORD will ·give you [strike you with] madness, blindness, and a confused mind.

29.verse: You will have to feel around ·in the daylight [at noon] like a blind person in darkness. You will ·fail in everything you do [not succeed in your way]. People will ·hurt [oppress] you and steal from you every day, and no one will ·save [help] you.

36.verse: The LORD will send you and the king whom you set over yourselves away to a nation neither you nor your ·ancestors [fathers] know, where you will serve other gods made of wood and stone.

38.verse: You will ·plant much seed in [carry out much seed to] your field, but your harvest will be small, because locusts will ·eat the crop [consume it].

43.verse: The ·foreigners [resident aliens] who live among you will ·get stronger and stronger [go higher and higher], and you will ·get weaker and weaker [go lower and lower].
